title: Russia tries to halt rouble slide as economic crisis returns to haunt Vladimir Putin
text:

Wed, Jul 29, 2015, 17:20 BST - UK Markets closed Russia tries to halt rouble slide as economic crisis returns to haunt Vladimir Putin By Roland Oliphant | Telegraph – 7 minutes ago Print 
Russia’s central bank halts daily purchases of foreign currency after the rouble hits 60 to the dollar 
Russia’s central bank halted daily purchases of foreign currency on Wednesday in an effort to stop a week-long slide of the rouble that has raised fears of a second currency collapse in a year. 
The decision came after the rouble hit 60 to the dollar on Tuesday, following five days of losses that threatened to undo months of recovery since an unprecedented fall over the winter. 
The rouble rallied by up to 1.4pc on Wednesday after the Bank of Russia announced a freeze on daily purchases of up to $200m in foreign currencies, citing “volatility”. 
One dollar was worth 59.6 roubles by 4pm in Moscow on Wednesday. 
The past week’s devaluation was driven by a slump in oil prices that analysts said would likely continue to put pressure on the rouble at least until the end of the year. 
Vladimir Putin, Russia's president 
Brent crude , the most important benchmark for Russia, was at $53 a barrel on Wednesday. 
The decision to halt purchases underlines the fine balance Russian policy makers need to maintain between keeping inflation under control and to maximising local currency earnings from dollar-denominated oil and gas exports. 
Russia has been locked in a financial crisis that has buffeted its currency and seen inflation soar, due to a combination of falling oil prices and international sanctions imposed by Western countries in retaliation for the annexation of Crimea and support for separatist forces in eastern Ukraine . 
Russia has been in recession for the first half of 2015 , and GDP is expected to shrink by 3pc-4pc by the end of the year. 
Volatility has been exacerbated by a decision in November last year to switch to a free-floating currency. 
The central bank spent nearly $90bn of its foreign currency reserves last year to control a dramatic slide in the value of the rouble, which has effectively halved the currency’s value since the Ukraine crisis began last year. 
The rouble's value has halved since the Ukraine crisis began last year 
Pressure on the rouble peaked with dramatic devaluations in December and January, when it slid to nearly 70 to the dollar. The rouble last touched 60 to the dollar on March 19. 
The central bank began foreign currency purchases to replenish its reserves in May, and has acquired some $10bn since. 
Tom Levinson, FX and rates chief strategist at Sberbank CIB, a state-owned investment bank, described winter’s crisis as a “perfect storm” of falling oil prices and intensification of the Ukraine war at a time when the central bank did not have enough tools to cope with it. 
While a repeat of that crisis seems unlikely, on-going difficulties appear to have left Russian policy makers struggling to balance simultaneous goals of boosting growth, suppressing inflation, replenishing foreign reserves and managing the exchange rate. 
“They started foreign currency purchases in May when the rouble dipped under 50, and they’ve stopped now when it hit 60. So although they say they’re allowing a free-floating ruble, it is difficult to get away from the thought that they have a band in mind,” said Mr Levinson.
